Award.AwardTitle: Improving Minority Participation and Completion through Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (IMPACTS)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Historically Black Colleges and Universities - Undergraduate Program provides support for projects to design, implement, and assess strategies that can lead to comprehensive institutional efforts to increase the number of students receiving undergraduate degrees in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) and enhance the quality of their preparation by strengthening STEM education and research. The one-year project at Dillard University seeks to establish the foundation for building STEM student success. The overall goal is to significantly increase the number of underrepresented minority students who complete STEM majors and enter into the STEM workforce or continue in a graduate program in a STEM field.

The objectives and activities are designed for reforming the curriculum and for recruiting and retaining STEM students. These activities include course redesign to align freshman year courses in mathematics and the sciences, a STEM Saturday Institute for high school students and their science teachers, and a summer bridge program for entering freshmen. Upper level STEM majors are involved in the project as mentors, tutors and facilitators. The activities and strategies are evidence-based and what is learned through this project can serve as a model for other small liberal arts institutions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
On May 26, 2017, Dillard University (DU) was awarded a National Science Foundation (NSF) Historically Black Colleges and Universities Undergraduate Program (HBCU-UP) Implementation Planning Grant. The grant allowed the initiation of the project “Improving Minority Participation and Completion through Science, Technology, Engineering, Mathematics” (IMPACTS@DU).  The overall goal of the project is to increase the number of underrepresented minority students who complete STEM majors and enter into the STEM workforce and /or continue in a graduate program in a STEM field. Key activities of the planning grant focused on curriculum redesign with technology infusion and recruitment and retention.

Curriculum Redesign and Technology Infusion:  STEM majors at Dillard account for twenty-three percent of the total enrollment and females account for seventy-three percent of the 299 STEM majors.  The number of first-year students requiring remedial math increased to approximately fifty percent during the 2017-2018 Academic Year. Retaining and moving these students through the curriculum is a major concern.  To address this concern, enhancing and updating the curriculum of STEM gateway courses and instructional approaches were initiated. A major outcome was the development and implementation of a co-requisite course, MAT 121A Integrated College Algebra. This course will alleviate the need for a separate Developmental Math course for students requiring remediation and will allow students to move forward in their science courses.  For the pilot study, incoming first-year students who did not meet the required ACT or SAT scores for placement into MAT 121 College Algebra were encouraged to attend the Emerging Scholars Program (ESP).  ESP usually requires students to enroll in the developmental math course, MAT109; however, during the summer of 2018, students were enrolled in the co-requisite algebra course MAT121A.  Students were required to attend tutoring services provided by the Division of Student Success and were provided peer-tutors. Twenty-seven students (100%) successfully completed the co-requisite course with a grade of C or better.  Full implementation of the course will take place during the fall 2018 semester.

During the planning grant, faculty of the Computer Science Program (CSP) reviewed its curriculum, researched the workforce needs, and agreed to implement several new courses and research that focus on cybersecurity and data analytics.  Funds from the grant allowed the replacement of decrepit computers. Thirty computers were purchased and equipped an entire computer lab. This lab will serve not only the CSP but the entire School of STEM.  The lab will be used for peer-tutoring and serve as a resource center for students without a computer or laptop. In addition, courses that require computer-based data acquisition and analysis will have access to the lab.

Saturday STEM Institute:  During the spring of 2018, 26 high school students and three teachers participated in the Saturday STEM Institute during the spring of 2018. The institute was conducted over four consecutive Saturdays and was led by STEM Program Coordinators.   The Institute was tailored towards enhancing high school students’ preparation for undergraduate studies and introduced participants to the STEM programs at DU.   Participants conducted experiments in various science, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) areas. The track for teachers and counselors focuses on benchmark measures in science and mathematics along with strategies to recruit students to major in STEM disciplines. 10 DU STEM majors served as assistants.  Stipends were provided for all participants. Outcome:  Four participants enrolled in DU in the fall of 2018; two participated in the Pre-Frist Year Bridge Program; one student successfully completed the MAT 121 Integrated College Algebra course as a participant in the ESP.

Pre-First Year Bridge Program:   Twenty-three incoming freshmen students participated in a ten-day residential bridge program at DU from June 13-23, 2018.  The program introduced students to the academic expectations of college and provided opportunities to frost social and academic relationships with peers, staff, and faculty.  Major components of the program include: (1) Molecular Biology Boot Camp that provide students an opportunity to gain hands-on research experience and exposed them to various molecular techniques; (2) Math Boot Camp that covered important math concepts, test-taking strategies, and tips to overcoming math anxiety; (3) English and Communication Boot Camp that exposed students to various  types of writing assignment and an opportunity to enhance their communication skills; (4) Orientation sessions that introduced students to STEM faculty, administers, and campus support program.  Participants were provided housing, meals, and travel stipends and mentored by five juniors and seniors STEM majors.  Assessment of the program includes student surveys and faculty reflection statements.  Outcome: All twenty-three participants completed the program successfully (100%); twenty-one (91%) enrolled at DU in the fall semester following the program and pursued a STEM major and was supported by a book voucher valued at $1,000.00.

In summary, results from the planning grant will be used as the foundation for the development and submission of a full HBCU-UP Implementation Grant.
